name: Walli Asr Halal Butcher Shop
penalty_amount:
Penalty for offences 1 and 2: $1,500 each
Penalty for offences 3 and 4: $2,500 each
finereason:
The defendant company, in respect of section 18(2) of the Food Act 2003, falsely described the nature and substance of the food in promoting its sale, namely:

Falsely described minced meat that was displayed for sale and was labelled as ‘beef’, when it contained both beef (bovine) and lamb (ovine) mince.
	Falsely described minced meat that was displayed for sale and was labelled as ‘lamb’, when it contained both lamb (ovine) and beef (bovine) mince.
The defendant company, in respect of section 21(2) of the Food Act 2003, sold food that failed to comply with the Food Standards Code, namely:

Sold raw minced meat described as ‘beef mince’ which contained the food additive sulphur dioxide at the level of 3000mg/kg. Raw minced meat is not permitted to contain any additives, including sulphur dioxide by Standard 1.3.1 and Section S15-5 - Item 8.1 of Schedule 15 under the Food Standards Code.
	Sold raw minced meat described as ‘lamb mince’ which contained the food additive sulphur dioxide at the level of 3600mg/kg. Raw minced meat is not permitted to contain any additives, including sulphur dioxide by Standard 1.3.1 and Section S15-5 - Item 8.1 of Schedule 15 under the Food Standards Code.

finereason:
The defendant company, in respect of section 21(2) of the Food Act 2003, sold food that failed to comply with the Food Standards Code, namely:

Sold food, namely raw meat, described as “Sausage Mince Chicken Mince” which had added in the food, the food additive sulphur dioxide at a level of 3200 mg/kg. Raw minced meat is not permitted to contain any additives, including sulphur dioxide by Standard 1.3.1 and Section S15-5 - Item 8.1 of Schedule 15.
	Sold food, namely raw meat, described as “Beef Mince” which had added in the food, the food additive sulphur dioxide at a level of 310 mg/kg. Raw minced meat is not permitted to contain any additives, including sulphur dioxide by Standard 1.3.1 and Section S15-5 - Item 8.1 of Schedule 15.
	Sold food, namely raw meat, described as “Lamb Premium Mince” which had added in the food, the food additive sulphur dioxide at a level of 340 mg/kg. Raw minced meat is not permitted to contain any additives, including sulphur dioxide by Standard 1.3.1 and Section S15-5 - Item 8.1 of Schedule 15.
	Sold food, namely raw meat, described as “Chicken Mince” which had added in the food, the food additive sulphur dioxide at a level of 3400 mg/kg. Raw minced meat is not permitted to contain any additives, including sulphur dioxide by Standard 1.3.1 and Section S15-5 - Item 8.1 of Schedule 15.
	Sold food, namely raw meat, described as “Lamb Fine Mince” which had added in the food, the food additive sulphur dioxide at a level of 840 mg/kg. Raw minced meat is not permitted to contain any additives, including sulphur dioxide by Standard 1.3.1 and Section S15-5 - Item 8.1 of Schedule 15.
	Sold food, namely raw meat, described as “Beef Mince” which had added in the food, the food additive sulphur dioxide at a level of 470 mg/kg. Raw minced meat is not permitted to contain any additives, including sulphur dioxide by Standard 1.3.1 and Section S15-5 - Item 8.1 of Schedule 15.
The defendant company, in respect of section 18(2) of the Food Act 2003, falsely described the nature and substance of the food in promoting its sale, namely:

Falsely described minced meat that was displayed for sale and was labelled as ‘Lamb Premium Mince’, an analysis of the minced meat revealed that the food contained another species of meat, namely of ‘cow’ (raw).
	Falsely described minced meat that was displayed for sale and was labelled as ‘Lamb Premium Mince’, an analysis of the minced meat revealed that the food contained another species of meat, namely of ‘cow’ (raw).

name: ALDI
penalty_amount:
Section 21(1) Offences 1 - 3: $3,000 per offence
Section 17(1) Offence: $1,000 $10,000 $2,137
finereason:
The defendant company was convicted of the following three offences for breaches of section 21(1) of the Food Act 2003, for failing to comply with Standard 3.2.2 of the Food Standards Code, namely:

Clause 6(1)(a), fail to store food in such a way that it is protected from the likelihood of contamination. Cucumbers that had been eaten by rats were found stored in the rear storage area and rat droppings found on stored food products.
	Clause 8(1)(a), fail to store food in such a way that it is protected from the likelihood of contamination. Food products on display were found to have been opened and contaminated by rats.
	Clause 24(1)(b), fail to take all practicable measures to prevent pests entering the food premises. Stainless steel ducting and the external perimeter wall at the loading dock were not adequately sealed to prevent the entry of rats.
The defendant company was also convicted of an offence for a breach of section 17(1) of the Food Act 2003, for handling food intended for sale in a manner which will render, or is likely to render, the food unsuitable.

	Clause 8(5), fail to display potentially hazardous food for sale under temperature control. Food found to be displayed at between 16.5 and 20°C.

The bread slicer, freezer and refrigerator seals, bench under the coffee machine, air conditioning unit, paper towel dispenser and light switches found to be unclean.

The defendant company, in respect of section 104(2) of the Food Act 2003, Carry on a food business without a licence., namely:

the defendant did carry on a food business, namely a meat business involving the operation of an abattoir, for which a licence is required by the regulations, namely clause 41 of the Food Regulation 2015 that states a person must not carry on a food business unless the person holds a licence authorising the carrying on of the food business, without holding such a licence.
The defendant company was convicted for 2 separate offences under section 21(1) of the Food Act 2003, for failing to comply with the Food Standards Code, namely:

Food Safety Standard 3.2.2 clause 7(1) in relation to the conduct of a food business, in that it did not take all practicable measures to process only safe and suitable food as required by subclause 7(1)(a).
	Food Safety Standard 3.2.3 clause 3 in relation to the conduct of such food business, in that it failed to comply with the requirement that the design and construction of the food premises (the abattoir) must be appropriate for the activities for which those premises were used, namely the slaughter and processing of animals.
